head.title: COMPARING THE EVOLUTION OF THE GALAXY DISK SIZES WITH CDM MODELS: THE HUBBLE DEEP FIELD

meta.name: keywords
meta.content: galaxies: fundamental parameters ‚Äì galaxies: evolution ‚Äì galaxies: formation

article.h1: COMPARING THE EVOLUTION OF THE GALAXY DISK SIZES WITH CDM MODELS: THE HUBBLE DEEP FIELD

span.span:
11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1} Osservatorio Astronomico di Roma, via di Frascati 33, I-00040 Monteporzio, Italy
22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2} European Southern Observatory, Karl Schwarzschild Strasse 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany

div.p: The intrinsic sizes of the field galaxies with I‚â§26ùêº26italic-I RELOP:less-than-or-equals NUMBER:26I\leq 26 in the Hubble and ESO-NTT Deep Fields are shown as a function of their redshifts and absolute magnitudes using photometric redshifts derived from the multicolor catalogs and are compared with the CDM predictions. Extending to lower luminosities and to higher zùëßitalic-zz our previous analysis performed on the NTT field alone, we find that the distribution of the galaxy disk sizes at different cosmic epochs is within the range predicted by typical CDM models. However, the observed size distribution of faint (MB>-19subscriptùëÄùêµ19italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:19M_{B}>-19) galaxies is skewed with respect to the CDM predictions and an excess of small-size disks (Rd<2subscriptùëÖùëë2italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:2R_{d}<2 kpc) is already present at z‚àº0.5similar-toùëß0.5italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5z\sim 0.5. The excess persists up to z‚àº3similar-toùëß3italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:3z\sim 3 and involves brighter galaxies . Such an excess may be reduced if luminosity-dependent effects, like starburst activity in interacting galaxies, are included in the physical mechanisms governing the star formation history in CDM models.

article.div: galaxies: fundamental parameters ‚Äì galaxies: evolution ‚Äì galaxies: formation

div.p: The understanding of galaxy formation has recently undergone an appreciable progress. Observationally, this is due to photometric and spectroscopic information in deep galaxy fields. A corresponding theoretical progress has been achieved by the developement of semi-analytical approaches including the gas cooling and star formation processes into the well developed hierarchical clustering theories for dark matter (DM) halos; this allows to relate the galaxy DM circular velocities to observable, luminous properties. In this context, the Tully-Fisher (TF) relation represents a typical test for the present theoretical models, as it relates the total luminosity of a disk galaxy to its halo circular velocity.

However, from an observational point of view, the measure of circular velocity is limited to bright nearby spirals and a few very bright galaxies at intermediate redshifts (e.g. Vogt et al. 1997). Extending the TF relation to fainter/distant spirals is essential to test the evolution in the Lùêøitalic-LL, zùëßitalic-zz plane of the M/LùëÄùêøitalic-M MULOP:divide italic-LM/L ratio predicted by CDM theories.

An alternative statistical approach to connect the luminous and dynamical properties of galaxy disks is based on the size-luminosity relation, once a specific model is assumed to connect size to circular velocity. This has the advantage of exploring the dynamical evolution over a wide range of luminosities and redshifts.

In a previous paper (Poli et al. 1999, Paper I) we applied this novel approach to the ESO-NTT Deep Field (Arnouts et al. 1999) to derive morphological information for the galaxies in the field down to I=25ùêº25italic-I RELOP:equals NUMBER:25I=25 after appropriate seeing deconvolution. The derived intrinsic angular sizes were then converted into physical sizes adopting photometric redshifts for each galaxy in the catalog (Fontana et al. 1999a). The distribution of sizes in the Lùêøitalic-LL, zùëßitalic-zz plane were compared with predictions of CDM semi-analytic models of galaxy formation (e.g. Cole et al. 1994, Baugh et al. 1998) complemented with the specific size-velocity relation worked out by Mo, Mao, & White (1998) for rotationally supported disks. This analysis showed an excess of small-size low luminosity galaxies at small-intermediate redshifts. However, the sample magnitude limit did not allow an assessment of this excess at higher redshifts. Here we want to extend the study to higher zùëßitalic-zz and lower Lùêøitalic-LL using the available data in the Hubble Deep field North where morphological information on the faint galaxy sample is available in the literature (Abraham et al. 1996; Odewahn et al. 1996; Driver et al. 1998; Marleau & Simard 1999). This will allow to assess if the excess observed at intermediate redshifts is an evolutionary effect or if it is present also at higher zùëßitalic-zz, indicating the presence of remarkable physical processes not included in the standard CDM models.

The morphological information on the galaxies in the Hubble Deep Field north was obtained using the galaxy catalog by Marleau & Simard (1999) where the structural parameter values were derived from the intensity profile fitting. Exponential profiles were assumed for the disk component and a final characteristic disk radius in arcsec was computed for all the galaxies up to I‚âÉ26similar-to-or-equalsùêº26italic-I RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:26I\simeq 26.
The HDF-N galaxy catalog has been joined with the NTT Deep Field catalog used in Paper I limited to I‚âÉ25similar-to-or-equalsùêº25italic-I RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:25I\simeq 25.

To each galaxy in the joined catalog, a photometric redshift estimate was assigned with the same best fitting procedure applied in Paper I and in Giallongo et al. 1998. This was obtained through a comparison of the observed colors with those predicted by spectral synthesis models (Bruzual & Charlot 1996) including UV absorption by the intergalactic medium and dust reddening. The aperture magnitudes used to estimate the galaxy colors and the I total magnitude for each galaxy were extracted from the catalog by Fernandez-Soto et al. (1999). The catalog of the photometric redshifts is presented in Fontana et al. 1999a. The resulting typical redshift accuracy is Œî‚Å¢z‚âÉ0.06similar-to-or-equalsŒîùëß0.06Delta italic-z RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.06\Delta z\simeq 0.06 up to z‚àº1.5similar-toùëß1.5italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.5z\sim 1.5 and Œî‚Å¢z‚àº0.3similar-toŒîùëß0.3Delta italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.3\Delta z\sim 0.3 at larger redshifts.

As derived in other fields of similar depth, the bulk of the galaxies is concentrated at intermediate redshifts z‚àº0.5-1similar-toùëß0.51italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1z\sim 0.5-1 with a tail in the distribution up to z‚àº6similar-toùëß6italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:6z\sim 6.

In order to verify the effects of the background noise on the measured sizes of the faint galaxies in the HDF we have performed a set of simulations specifically designed to reproduce the typical conditions of real data. The same test has been performed in Paper I for the galaxies in the NTT Deep Field.

The intensity profiles were reproduced as in the observed HDF images assuming the same pixel sampling. Assuming an intrinsic exponential profile, a series of synthetic images were constructed using different half light radii ranging from rh‚Å¢l=0.1subscriptùëü‚Ñéùëô0.1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1r_{hl}=0.1‚Äù to rh‚Å¢l=0.9subscriptùëü‚Ñéùëô0.9italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.9r_{hl}=0.9‚Äù with a step of 0.1‚Äù. An average of 25 random objects were computed for each radius, assuming a total magnitude of I‚àº26similar-toùêº26italic-I RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:26I\sim 26 which is the limiting magnitude of the morphological galaxy sample. The background subtracted image of a bright star was selected in the field to reproduce the instrumental PSF. Its normalized profile was then convolved with the synthetic images of the disk galaxies. The convolved two dimensional profiles were randomly inserted in regions of the HDF far from very bright objects to reproduce the observed HDF galaxies with the appropriate pixel size and noise levels. Finally, the multigaussian deconvolution technique was applied to the synthetic data as in Paper I.

We first notice that there is no selection bias against galaxies with large size (rh‚Å¢l‚àº1similar-tosubscriptùëü‚Ñéùëô1italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1r_{hl}\sim 1 arcsec) and low surface brightness down to I‚âÉ26similar-to-or-equalsùêº26italic-I RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:26I\simeq 26 since all the synthetic objects were detected. The results are shown in Fig.¬†1, where the error bars represent the dispersion around the mean due to noise in the background subtraction. A good match between the intrinsic and measured half light radii was obtained up to rh‚Å¢l‚àº0.7similar-tosubscriptùëü‚Ñéùëô0.7italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.7r_{hl}\sim 0.7 arcsec. For larger values, a slight underestimate in the measured values appears at the sample limiting magnitude. In any case it can be seen that, even for the faint galaxies with I‚àº26similar-toùêº26italic-I RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:26I\sim 26, the overall correlation between intrinsic and measured half-light radii is preserved in such a way that an intrinsically large, faint object, e.g. with rh‚Å¢l‚àº0.7‚Ä≤‚Ä≤similar-tosubscriptùëü‚Ñéùëôsuperscript0.7‚Ä≤‚Ä≤italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.7 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{hl}\sim 0.7^{\prime\prime}, can not be detected as a small sized one, e.g. with rh‚Å¢l‚àº0.1‚Ä≤‚Ä≤similar-tosubscriptùëü‚Ñéùëôsuperscript0.1‚Ä≤‚Ä≤italic-r POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-h italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start SUPOP:prime SUPOP:prime POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endr_{hl}\sim 0.1^{\prime\prime}. The simulation shows that the fraction of small size galaxies present in the HDF morphological catalog is real and is not due to intrinsically larger objects which have been shrunk by noise effects.

section.h2: 3 THE DISTRIBUTION OF THE GALAXY SIZES IN LUMINOSITY AND REDSHIFT: A COMPARISON WITH CDM MODELS

div.p: We have computed the disk linear size RdsubscriptùëÖùëëitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{d} and the absolute blue magnitude for each galaxy in the catalog using the color estimated redshifts as discussed in the previous section.

In Fig. 2 we plot the distribution of the observed sizes for the HDF galaxies as a function of luminosity in four different redshift intervals. The filled circles represent HDF spirals with bulge-to-total ratio in the range 0.05<B/T<0.750.05ùêµùëá0.75NUMBER:0.05 RELOP:less-than italic-B MULOP:divide italic-T RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.750.05<B/T<0.75 while asterisks represent galaxies with B/T<0.05ùêµùëá0.05italic-B MULOP:divide italic-T RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.05B/T<0.05, most of which of irregular morphology (Marleau & Simard 1998; Schade et al. 1998). HDF galaxies with B/T>0.75ùêµùëá0.75italic-B MULOP:divide italic-T RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:0.75B/T>0.75 are excluded since they are bulge dominated systems. The NTTDF galaxies of Paper I are also shown as empty squares.

We also show in the shaded area the prediction of our rendition of the standard semi-analytical CDM models. This relates the luminous properties of galaxies to their circular velocity including the hierarchical merging of dark matter halos, the merging of galaxies inside the halos, the gas cooling, the star formation and the Supernovae feedback associated with the galaxies. Finally, the circular velocity of the halos is connected to the disk scale length using the Mo, Mao & White (1998) model; the latter correlation depends on the dimensionless angular momentum ŒªùúÜitalic-lambda\lambda whose lognormal distribution p‚Å¢(Œª)ùëùùúÜitalic-p OPEN:( italic-lambda CLOSE:)p(\lambda) is given in Mo et al. (1998). The shaded area in Fig. 2 corresponds to that allowed for 0.025<Œª<0.10.025ùúÜ0.1NUMBER:0.025 RELOP:less-than italic-lambda RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.10.025<\lambda<0.1, the values corresponding to the 10% and 90% points of p‚Å¢(Œª)ùëùùúÜitalic-p OPEN:( italic-lambda CLOSE:)p(\lambda). The solid line corresponds to Œª=0.05ùúÜ0.05italic-lambda RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.05\lambda=0.05, the 50% point of p‚Å¢(Œª)ùëùùúÜitalic-p OPEN:( italic-lambda CLOSE:)p(\lambda). The full p‚Å¢(Œª)ùëùùúÜitalic-p OPEN:( italic-lambda CLOSE:)p(\lambda) distribution is taken into account in the differential size distribution of galaxies with I<26ùêº26italic-I RELOP:less-than NUMBER:26I<26 (normalized to the total number) shown in Fig.¬†3 for different redshift bins. A tilted CDM power spectrum of perturbations with n=0.8ùëõ0.8italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.8n=0.8 in an Œ©=1Œ©1Omega RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\Omega=1 Universe with Ho=50subscriptùêªùëú50italic-H POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-o POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:50H_{o}=50 km/s/Mpc has been used.

The full details of our semi-analytic model are given in Appendix A of Paper I together with the adopted set of star formation and feedback parameters. The latter set was chosen as to optimize the matching to the local I-band Tully-Fisher relation for bright galaxies and the B-band galaxy luminosity function. Note that, since the disk velocity is ‚àºsimilar-toRELOP:similar-to\sim 20% higher than that of the DM, a small offset (‚àº0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 mag) between the predicted and the observed Tully-Fisher relation is present (see Fig.¬†9 of Paper I).

Fig.¬†2 shows that at z<1ùëß1italic-z RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1z<1 and for faint magnitudes (MB>-19subscriptùëÄùêµ19italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:19M_{B}>-19), the observed sizes tend to occupy preferentially the small size region below the 50% locus of the angular momentum distribution. Correspondingly, Fig. 3 shows the excess of small (Rd<2subscriptùëÖùëë2italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:2R_{d}<2 kpc) size galaxies with respect to the CDM predictions. Indeed, for MB>-19subscriptùëÄùêµ19italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:19M_{B}>-19, the predicted average disk size is 2.1 Kpc while the observed one is 1.4 Kpc. These results are similar to those presented in Paper I, although extended down to MB<-16subscriptùëÄùêµ16italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:16M_{B}<-16 and with a larger statistics.

The excess becomes less evident at brighter magnitudes, in agreement with recent studies (Lilly et al. 1998, Simard et al. 1999) which indicate little evolution in the morphological properties of bright spirals in the CFRS sample up to z‚àº1similar-toùëß1italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1z\sim 1. At z‚â≥1greater-than-or-equivalent-toùëß1italic-z RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to NUMBER:1z\gtrsim 1, the larger statistics available with the present sample (with respect to that used in Paper I) shows that the excess persists and involves brighter galaxies (MB‚â≥-20greater-than-or-equivalent-tosubscriptùëÄùêµ20italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than-or-equivalent-to ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20M_{B}\gtrsim-20) with an observed average Rd‚âÉ1.3similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëÖùëë1.3italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1.3R_{d}\simeq 1.3 kpc respect to the predicted Rd‚âÉ1.9similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëÖùëë1.9italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1.9R_{d}\simeq 1.9 kpc. In addition, the excess appears for all the galaxies in the sample regardless of their morphological classification and so does not depend on the selection procedure adopted for the spiral sample. Furthermore, the above excesses cannot be due to the offset (only ‚àº0.5similar-toabsent0.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.5\sim 0.5 mag) between the observed and the theoretical Tully-Fisher relation, as confirmed by the good agreement of the Rd-MBsubscriptùëÖùëësubscriptùëÄùêµitalic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:endR_{d}-M_{B} relation at the bright end.

In summary, Figs. 2 and 3 indicate that small-size galaxies appear smaller and/or brighter than predicted by CDM at all zùëßitalic-zz (indeed, even more at high zùëßitalic-zz). Within the framework of the adopted standard scenario of disk formation, which assumes the conservation of the specific baryonic angular momentum (Mo, Mao & White 1999), a viable solution consists in introducing a brightening of small-size galaxies. In particular, we note that shifting the predicted curves toward higher luminosities results in a better fit to the data. At z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1italic-z RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:1z\lesssim 1 the best fitting shift is ‚àº1similar-toabsent1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\sim 1 mag, while at larger zùëßitalic-zz the best fitting shift is ‚àº1.5similar-toabsent1.5RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1.5\sim 1.5 mag (Fig.¬†2).

The present analysis performed on a larger and deeper sample, confirms our previous findings at z‚â≤1less-than-or-similar-toùëß1italic-z RELOP:less-than-or-similar-to NUMBER:1z\lesssim 1 (Paper I), where an excess of faint (MB>-19subscriptùëÄùêµ19italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:19M_{B}>-19), small-size (Rd<2subscriptùëÖùëë2italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:2R_{d}<2 kpc) galaxies with respect to the CDM predictions was found. The results presented here show that the excess persits even at higher redshifts (1<z<3.51ùëß3.5NUMBER:1 RELOP:less-than italic-z RELOP:less-than NUMBER:3.51<z<3.5) and for brighter galaxies (MB>-20subscriptùëÄùêµ20italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than ADDOP:minus NUMBER:20M_{B}>-20). Several processes may be responsible for the above excess (see Paper I), like the non conservation of the gas angular momentum during the collapse in the Mo et al. model. Alternatively, within the Mo et al. framework for disk formation, a possible explanation can be sought in luminosity-dependent effects related to the physical mechanisms involved in star formation activity already at high zùëßitalic-zz. Indeed, a shift of the shaded region (the CDM prediction) by ‚àº1similar-toabsent1RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1\sim 1 mag at z<1ùëß1italic-z RELOP:less-than NUMBER:1z<1 and 1.5 mag at z>1.5ùëß1.5italic-z RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1.5z>1.5 is sufficient to reconcile the CDM predictions with the observations.

Such shift could be due to the starbust brightening of the numerous small size galaxies subject to close encounters/interactions. This brightening would have the advantage of explaining at the same time the flat shape of the global cosmological star formation rate MÀô*subscriptÀôùëÄOVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\dot{M}_{*} observed at z>1.5ùëß1.5italic-z RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:1.5z>1.5 in deep surveys (Steidel et al. 1999; Fontana et al. 1999b) which results a factor ‚àº5-10similar-toabsent510RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:5 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:10\sim 5-10 higher than predicted by CDM. Since the SFR is proportional to the UV-B luminosity, a brightening of the predicted luminosities in small size galaxies by ‚àº1-2similar-toabsent12RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus NUMBER:2\sim 1-2 mag is needed in both cases. The interaction rate needed to reconcile the CDM evolutionary scenario with the various observables can be derived by the following simple considerations. The SFR in a galaxy halo from a cool gas of mass Mc‚Å¢o‚Å¢o‚Å¢lsubscriptùëÄùëêùëúùëúùëôitalic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-o italic-o italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:endM_{cool} can be written as MÀô*‚âàfg‚Å¢a‚Å¢s‚Å¢Mc‚Å¢o‚Å¢o‚Å¢l/œÑi+(1-fg‚Å¢a‚Å¢s)‚Å¢Mc‚Å¢o‚Å¢o‚Å¢l/œÑ*subscriptÀôùëÄsubscriptùëìùëîùëéùë†subscriptùëÄùëêùëúùëúùëôsubscriptùúèùëñ1subscriptùëìùëîùëéùë†subscriptùëÄùëêùëúùëúùëôsubscriptùúèOVERACCENT:dot ARG:start italic-M ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g italic-a italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-o italic-o italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:minus italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g italic-a italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-M POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c italic-o italic-o italic-l POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\dot{M}_{*}\approx f_{gas}\,M_{cool}/\tau_{i}+(1-f_{gas})\,M_{cool}/\tau_{*}, where fg‚Å¢a‚Å¢ssubscriptùëìùëîùëéùë†italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g italic-a italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:endf_{gas} is the fraction of gas converted in stars due to interactions, œÑisubscriptùúèùëñitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{i} is the timescale for interactions and œÑ*subscriptùúèitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{*} is the quiescent star formation time scale. While only the latter term is usually included in the CDM models, we note that for fg‚Å¢a‚Å¢s‚àº0.1similar-tosubscriptùëìùëîùëéùë†0.1italic-f POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g italic-a italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.1f_{gas}\sim 0.1 a œÑisubscriptùúèùëñitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{i} shorter than œÑ*subscriptùúèitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{*} by about a factor 100 would be implied to obtain a SFR consistent with the high zùëßitalic-zz data; for the population of small galaxies (dominating at high zùëßitalic-zz) with a circular velocity vc‚â≤less-than-or-similar-tosubscriptùë£ùëêabsentitalic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than-or-similar-tov_{c}\lesssim 100 km/s (corresponding to œÑ*‚âà5subscriptùúè5italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:5\tau_{*}\approx 5 Gyr, see Cole et al. 1994) this would imply œÑi‚âà0.1subscriptùúèùëñ0.1italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:approximately-equals NUMBER:0.1\tau_{i}\approx 0.1 Gyr, in fact close to the dynamical time scale of these systems at z‚àº2similar-toùëß2italic-z RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:2z\sim 2. Note that for larger (vc>200subscriptùë£ùëê200italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:greater-than NUMBER:200v_{c}>200 km/s) disk galaxies, œÑ*‚àºvc-1.5similar-tosubscriptùúèsuperscriptsubscriptùë£ùëê1.5italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-c POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1.5 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\tau_{*}\sim v_{c}^{-1.5} becomes smaller while œÑi‚àº1/Ngsimilar-tosubscriptùúèùëñ1subscriptùëÅùëîitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:1 MULOP:divide italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{i}\sim 1/N_{g} remains large due to their small number density NgsubscriptùëÅùëîitalic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:endN_{g} (Cavaliere & Vittorini 1999), so that the quiescent star formation mode prevails for these systems; in addition since Ng‚àº(1+z)3similar-tosubscriptùëÅùëîsuperscript1ùëß3italic-N POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to OPEN:( NUMBER:1 ADDOP:plus italic-z CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endN_{g}\sim(1+z)^{3} for all the galaxies, the interaction time scale œÑisubscriptùúèùëñitalic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{i} becomes ineffective at small zùëßitalic-zz.

Detailed implementation of the interaction-driven star formation mode in semi-analytical models will soon provide a more quantitative test for the importance of this physical mechanism in determining the galaxy properties at high zùëßitalic-zz.

div.p: Fig.¬†1. Deconvolved half light radii as a function of true values in simulated data of the HDF. Error bars are one sigma confidence intervals.

br.p: Fig.¬†2. Distribution of galaxies in the luminosity-size plane in four redshift intervals. The disk radii are in kpc. Empty squares are NTTDF galaxies; filled circles are HDF spiral galaxies with 0.05<B/T<0.750.05ùêµùëá0.75NUMBER:0.05 RELOP:less-than italic-B MULOP:divide italic-T RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.750.05<B/T<0.75; stars are galaxies with B/T<0.05ùêµùëá0.05italic-B MULOP:divide italic-T RELOP:less-than NUMBER:0.05B/T<0.05 most of which with irregular morphology. The shaded region represents the region allowed by the model. The upper and lower lines correspond to the 90% and 10% points of the angular momentum distribution. The solid line corresponds to the 50% point of the same distribution (see the text for details).

Fig.¬†3. Size distribution of the low and high luminosity spiral galaxies in the HDF and NTTDF shown in Fig.¬†2. The corresponding curves are the distributions predicted by the CDM model. An excess of small size galaxies with respect to the CDM predictions is apparent at Rd‚âÉ1similar-to-or-equalssubscriptùëÖùëë1italic-R POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-d POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:1R_{d}\simeq 1 kpc.
